What is Verus Vault, and how does it provide an additional layer of security and decentralized funds recovery for VerusID holders?

Verus Vault is a security feature that allows VerusID holders to lock their identities, effectively protecting their funds from theft, even if their private key is compromised. When a VerusID is locked with Vault, the funds associated with that identity cannot be spent until it is unlocked. However, the funds can still be staked on the Verus network, earning rewards, and can still receive incoming funds.

To use Verus Vault, you need to have at least one primary identity and one revocation/recovery ID configured. The revocation and recovery authority identities can still revoke and recover a locked VerusID, bypassing the lock. Meanwhile, anyone with only the primary keys, including a multisig of primary keys, must first unlock the identity and then wait for a predetermined unlock time before they can access the funds.

This feature provides a decentralized solution to the "5-dollar wrench attack," where an attacker physically forces the owner to unlock their wallet. By setting a delay, such as 24 hours, on the unlock process, you can ensure that even if an attacker gains access to your primary keys, they will not be able to quickly drain your funds.

Verus Vault not only protects your funds but also provides security for your IDs and NFTs. It offers time locks for various purposes, such as vesting schedules, trusts, and inheritance. With Verus Vault, you can safeguard your assets and generational blockchain wealth from common forms of crypto loss or theft, without relying on a traditional bank.
